name: Dividing whole numbers by unit fractions

skills.name: Divide proper fractions in the form: Integer ÷ Fraction
Dividing an integer by a unit fraction using a bar model and fact families
Dividing an integer by a unit fraction

explanations.A: I think you may have multiplied. 2 ÷ 1/5 means how many times does 1/5 fit into 2?
explanations.C: Sometimes we "flip" a fraction we're dividing by, but we don't flip a number to be divided.
explanations.D: Sometimes we "flip" a fraction we're dividing by, but we don't also flip a number to be divided.

explanations.A: I think you may have multiplied. 3 ÷ 1/6 means how many times does 1/6 fit into 3?
explanations.B: Sometimes we "flip" a fraction we're dividing by, but we don't flip a number to be divided.
explanations.C: Sometimes we "flip" a fraction we're dividing by, but we don't also flip a number to be divided.

explanations.A: Read the question carefully, we want to know how many times 1/5 goes into 1 whole. How many fifths fit in the bar?
explanations.B: The bar for one whole is split into five equal pieces; there are 5 fifths in 1 whole.
explanations.C: Not quite, try counting the fifths in the bar again.
explanations.D: Make sure you are looking at the bottom bar, which has been split into fifths (1/5). How many pieces are there?

explanations.A: Read the question carefully, we want to know how many times 1/6 goes into 1 whole. How many sixths fit in the bar?
explanations.B: Make sure you are looking at the bottom bar, which has been split into sixths (1/6). How many pieces are there?
explanations.C: Not quite, try counting the sixths in the bar again.
explanations.D: The bar for one whole is split into six equal pieces; there are 6 sixths in 1 whole.

explanations.A: I think you might have tried to divide using Keep Flip Change but flipped the wrong fraction... Using the bar model, can you count how many times 1/3 goes into 2?
explanations.B: Each 1 whole is split into three 1/3 pieces, so in 2 wholes there are six lots of 1/3.
explanations.C: Not quite, make sure you are just counting how many 1/3 pieces there are in the diagram.
explanations.D: There are 3 thirds in 1 whole, but we have 2 wholes. How many 1/3 pieces are there altogether in the diagram?

explanations.A: I think you might have tried to divide using "Keep Flip Change" but flipped the wrong fraction... Using the bar model, can you count how many times 1/4 goes into 2?
explanations.B: Not quite, make sure you are just counting how many 1/4 pieces there are in the diagram.
explanations.C: Each 1 whole is split into four 1/4 pieces, so in 2 wholes there are eight lots of 1/4.
explanations.D: There are 4 quarters in 1 whole, but we have 2 wholes. How many 1/4 pieces are there altogether in the diagram?

explanations.A: 5 ÷ 1/6 is asking how many times 1/6 goes into 5. The box tells us that there are 30 lots of 1/6 in 5.
explanations.B: I think you might have multiplied 1/5 by 1/6 but that's not quite right. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times 1/6 goes into 5?
explanations.C: I think you might have multiplied 5 by 1/6 but that's not quite right. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times 1/6 goes into 5?
explanations.D: Not quite, we want to see how many sixths go into 5. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times 1/6 goes into 5?

explanations.A: 4 ÷ 1/3 is asking how many times 1/3 goes into 4. The box tells us that there are 12 lots of 1/3 in 4.
explanations.B: I think you might have multiplied 1/4 x 1/3 but that's not quite right. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times does 1/3 go into 4?
explanations.C: I think you have multiplied 12 by 3 but that's not quite right. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times does 1/3 go into 4?
explanations.D: I think you have multiplied 4 by 1/3 but that's not quite right. Think about a simpler fact family like 5 x 2 = 10. From this we know that 10 ÷ 2 = 5. Can you use this to work out how many times does 1/3 go into 4?

explanations.A: Remember if you're using the Keep Flip Change method you need to flip the second fraction before multiplying... How many times does 1/4 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 8?
explanations.B: Remember if you're using the Keep Flip Change method you need to flip the second fraction but not the first... How many times does 1/4 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 8?
explanations.C: There are four quarters in 1 whole, so in 8 wholes there are 8 x 4 = 32. Or we can say 8/1 ÷ 1/4 = 8/1 x 4/1 = 32/1 = 32.
explanations.D: Remember if you're using the Keep Flip Change method you need to flip the second fraction not the first... How many times does 1/4 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 8?

explanations.A: Remember if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method you need to flip the second fraction before multiplying... How many times does 1/5 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 9?
explanations.B: Remember if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method you need to flip the second fraction and then multiply it by the first fraction... How many times does 1/5 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 9?
explanations.C: Remember if you're using the "Keep Flip Change" method you need to flip the second fraction not the first... How many times does 1/5 go into 1? So how many times will it go into 9?
explanations.D: There are five fifths in 1 whole, so in 9 wholes there are 9 x 5 = 45. Or we can say 9/1 ÷ 1/5 = 9/1 x 5/1 = 45/1 = 45.
